metadata.paragraph_text_preview: On March 1, 2025, Catholic Charities, Diocese of Forth Worth (CCFW) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. D...

target:
On March 1, 2025, Catholic Charities, Diocese of Forth Worth (CCFW) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its Secretary, Robert F. Kennedy. CCFW assists refugees and immigrants with documented legal status and is responsible for coordinating the Refugee Resettlement Program across the state. The plaintiff challenged the Trump Administration's ongoing freeze of money that had been previously delegated and committed to the plaintiff for the care of lawful refugees.

On January 27, 2025, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) issued a memorandum directing all federal agencies to "temporarily pause all activities related to obligation or disbursement of all Federal financial assistance." While the OMB rescinded the memo less than two days later, the plaintiffs pointed to another case, National Council of Nonprofits v. Office of Management and Budget [../../../../case/45977/], in which Judge AliKhan had found that the Administration was still seeking to restrict federal funding and issued a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) requiring federal agencies not to freeze funding.

The plaintiffs alleged that, since January 30, they had made multiple requests for payment from the Payment Management Services (PMS) system, but they had received no funds, and HHS had failed to provide a legal rationale for the failure. The plaintiffs requested declaratory and injunctive relief under the Administrative Procedure Act, alleging that the defendants' actions were a violation of their statutory authority, the Appropriations Clause, and the Spending Clause, and were arbitrary and capricious. The plaintiffs asked the court to declare the defendants' actions unlawful and to enjoin the defendants from implementing a funding freeze against CCFW in the future.

On March 2, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO). The case was assigned to District Judge Loren L. AliKhan because of the case's relation to National Council of Nonprofits. Judge AliKhan held a hearing on the plaintiffs' motion on March 12.

Following a status conference on March 13, the court instructed the parties to file multiple status reports on the current status of the plaintiffs' payment requests. On April 11, the plaintiffs reported that they were able to draw down their funds within 24-48 hours. Given this development, the court ordered the parties to file another joint status report on April 30, unless the parties dismissed the case before then.

On April 29, 2025, the parties moved to dismiss the case as moot. The court dismissed the case the same day.

This case is closed.
target_paragraph: On March 1, 2025, Catholic Charities, Diocese of Forth Worth (CCFW) filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and its Secretary, Robert F. Kennedy. CCFW assists refugees and immigrants with documented legal status and is responsible for coordinating the Refugee Resettlement Program across the state. The plaintiff challenged the Trump Administration's ongoing freeze of money that had been previously delegated and committed to the plaintiff for the care of lawful refugees.

annotation.explanation: March 1, 2025

Plaintiffs: Individual, described as Catholic Charities, Diocese of Forth Worth (CCFW), which assists refugees and immigrants with documented legal status and coordinates the Refugee Resettlement Program across the state.
Plaintiff: Catholic Charities, Diocese of Forth Worth (CCFW), which assists refugees and immigrants with documented legal status and coordinates the Refugee Resettlement Program across the state.
Defendant: Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
Defendant: Robert F. Kennedy, Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).
Plaintiff CCFW filed suit on March 1, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia against HHS and the HHS Secretary, Robert F. Kennedy.
Background: CCFW assists lawful refugees and immigrants and coordinates the state Refugee Resettlement Program.
Challenged action: An ongoing federal funding freeze of previously allocated funds for refugee care.
Complaint filed initiating the case in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on March 1, 2025.

Office of Management and Budget [../../../../case/45977/], in which Judge AliKhan had found that the Administration was still seeking to restrict federal funding and issued a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO) requiring federal agencies not to freeze funding.

Administrative Procedure Act (APA) (including arbitrary and capricious agency action)

annotation.explanation: Declaratory relief under the Administrative Procedure Act—a declaration that the defendants' actions are unlawful.
Injunctive relief—an order enjoining the defendants from implementing a funding freeze against CCFW in the future.
